abstracts.cdata!:
The project outcome is satisfactory,
            with a likely sustainability, and substantial institutional
            development impacts. Among the several lessons learned, it
            is emphasized that institutional stability is crucial to
            project success; thus, the Bank should be informed of
            upcoming institutional changes, and potential implications
            to the project, and as well, the Project Unit should be
            given clear terms of reference, to minimize outside negative
            influences. The nature of eco-tourism, and the economic
            value of natural habitats is just beginning to be
            recognized, but the approach to interfacing the work of
            reserve managers, with that of local communities, i.e.,
            participation through formal surveys, and consultations
            during the development of the Sustainable Development
            Strategies, provided a key lesson to be expanded by the
            protected area managers in the future. Regardless of
            success, the project was somehow overly ambitious, both in
            terms of implementation plans, and objectives, and, in terms
            of an over optimistic implementation schedule. It is thus
            suggested that explicit targets, and performance indicators
            be in place at the onset of the project, to help identify
            the success, cost-effectiveness, and basic usefulness of
            components throughout implementation. And, a number of
            causal factors conduced to a slower timeframe
            implementation, namely: GEF projects are inherently
            comprehensive, therefore complex, and, institutional
            capacity building is a process that takes time. Both the
            absence of performance indicators, and the implementation
            schedule are considered a design flaw, a lesson to be taken
            into account for subsequent operations.

1089575.trustfund:
TF020855-AUSTRIAN CONSULTANT TRUST FUND
            FOR E & C EUROPE,TF031024-POLAND & SLOVAK REPUBLIC -
            FORESTRY; BIODIVERSITY PROTECTION,TF031023-ECA REGION - FORESTRY
            BIODIVERSITY PRODUCTION,TF028644-GET-SLOVAK BIODIVERSITY
            PROTECTION PROJ.

abstracts.cdata!:
The Biodiversity Protection Project will
            protect and strengthen forest and related ecosystem
            biodiversity in the Slovak Republic, and will: (a) foster
            systems of financiallysustainable biodiversity protection in
            the Slovak Republic through the introduction of user fees,
            related charges for visitors and concessions to manage the
            areas within their determined carrying capacities and to
            evaluate the role that economic mechanisms might play in
            keeping visitation to levels below identified carrying
            capacities; (b) establish a three country mechanism
            (Ukraine, Poland and Slovak Republics) through the
            development of an International Trust for the Biodiversity
            Protection of the Eastern Carpathians whose income would be
            used to protect the biodiversity in this transboundary area.
            The project also will: (c) protect three zones of
            representative threatened ecosystems - alpine meadows,
            wetlands, and mountain forests; (d) support the activities
            of three transnational biodiversity protection networks; and
            (e) develop a conservation program to address priority
            issues such as privatization. The project will involve the
            following activities: (a) a biodiversity protection program;
            (b) a conservation program; and (c) an institutional
            infrastructure improvement program.
